 1. BACKGROUND A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Recognizing the importance of transport to national economic growth, the Government of Togo (GOT) has developed a Transport Sector Strategy (TSS) with the active participation of sector stakeholders and donors. This strategy, adopted in May 1996, is to be operationalized under the Government's ten-year Transport Sector Investment Program (TSIP) from 1997 to 2006. The TSIP comprises investments and institutional and policy reforms designed to support implementation of strategy objectives to rehabilitate road infrastructure, establish an effective road maintenance system and modernize the sector's institutional environment. The GOT has requested IDA assistance in financing the first, priority tranche of this program, aimed at improving the condition of transport infrastructure, and assuring sound management and sustainable autonomous development of the transport sector, with the active participation of the private sector and local communities. 1.2 Road transport carries 98 percent of demand for transport services, using a severely degraded road network. The priority program and the proposed IDA Credit project therefore focus primarily on the road subsector, through rehabilitation of infrastructure and establishment of a sustainable maintenance system. The priority program and proposed IDA Credit also support institutional strengthening for the transport sector as a whole. B. MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 1.3 Located on the Gulf of Guinea in Western Africa. Togo is a low-income country with a population of approximately 4 million and a 1994 per capita Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of US$ 390. Urban populations are growing at 6.5 percent per year, double the national average growth rate of 3.1 percent. Despite this high urban growth rate, it is expected that half of the country's population will still be living in rural areas by 2010, down from a 1993 level of 72 percent, maintaining the pressure on already fragile rural infrastructure. 1.4 The economy is based on three main areas of activity: agriculture, services and phosphate mining and export. Agriculture employs 75 percent of the active population, and accounts for 38 percent of GDP. The service sector, mainly commerce and transit activities, currently accounts for 36 percent of GDP. Phosphates make up 41 percent of exports. Transport, supporting these main engines of growth, is therefore central to the economy. Togo is one of the corridors to the Sahel (the Togolese corridor), in particular to Burkina Faso (to which it channels 31 percent of its overseas imports), and to a lesser
 2 extent to Niger, Mali, northern Ghana and northern Benin. The main transport infrastructure consists of a network of more than 3,000 km of major national roads, 276 km of operating rail lines and a deep water port in Lome. 1.5 Until the early 1990's, Togo was known for its political stability and strong economic growth. The political crisis of 1991-1993 resulted in a severe depression, from which the Togolese economy is just beginning to recover. The 1994 CFA Franc (CFAF) devaluation resulted in a 8.3 percent growth in GDP by 1995. However, 1995 GDP (217.2 billion in 1978 CFAF) still lags nearly 4 percent behind that of 1989 (225.3 billion in 1978 CFAF). Public finances have likewise improved somewhat since the crisis: the net deficit has dropped from a 1993post-crisis high of 15.3 percent of GDP to 8.4 percent in 1995, due to a combination of increased revenues and more contained State expenditures. Arrears payments have dropped to CFAF 77.8 billion on a total estimated, on December 31, 1994, at CFAF 108.9 billion, due to external debt forgiveness and rescheduling. 1.6 To promote sustainable economic growth, the GOT has engaged in a new development strategy, supported by the IDA Economic Recovery Adjustment Credit (ERAC) for the period 1996-1998. In line with the Bank's 1995 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Togo, ERAC's main objectives are to correct economic imbalances and to facilitate growth in equity. These objectives translate into sectoral measures to: (a) diversify agricultural production and exportation in which Togo has a comparative advantage in external markets; (b) regenerate the manufacturing sector through small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and private investment; (c) revive the service sector, in which Togolese economic agents have been successful in the past; (d) create an enabling environment to transform Lome into a regional trade and financial center; and (e) reduce State expenditures, particularly those that are not directly productive, and increase budgetary resource mobilization. 1.7 ERAC refocuses public expenditures to give priority to health, education, and the rehabilitation of basic economic and social infrastructure, such as roads, water and sanitation. Over the short term, the emphasis will be on the rehabilitation and maintenance of infrastructure using labor-intensive techniques to promote employment. The Transport Sector Strategy and the TSIP reflect these same priorities and focus on improving and maintaining the existing road infrastructure as a means of providing Togo with a competitive transport network. Restored transport competitiveness will enable the country to resume its significant role in regional trade, promote agricultural production, and reduce rural poverty. C. DEVELOPMENT CONSTRAINTS AND BROAD OBJECTIVES Country Assistance Strategy Linkages 1.8 The Bank's CAS for Togo promotes sustainable, private-sector led growth and poverty reduction. To achieve these objectives, Bank assistance takes a two-pronged approach, supporting: (a) Government efforts to mobilize and allocate resources
 3 effectively, and reform public enterprises; and (b) broad policy reforms and targeted investments to enhance participation in economic growth, especially by the poor, create a favorable environment for private sector development, and increase the efficiency and sustainability of natural resource management. Over the short-term, Bank assistance focuses on rehabilitating essential transport and energy infrastructure, and restoring social services, which suffered during the political crisis. In its current state, this infrastructure significantly reduces the development potential of the country. Throughout the assistance strategy, planned operations will emphasize strengthening public sector management of infrastructure and services. 1.9 The CAS identifies degraded physical infrastructure as a major constraint to development. Given the importance of transport to the national economy, and to regional development, the CAS places primary importance on rehabilitating Togo's transport infrastructure, improving sector management and service provision, and assuring the sector sustainability. Rehabilitation and sustainable management of the road subsector are a first priority for revitalizing the economy. Improvements in road infrastructure, services and management will revitalize the transit trade economy, boost agricultural production, create jobs and increase accessibility to services, especially in rural areas. 1.10 Accordingly, the proposed project focuses on rehabilitating vital road networks, improving their management, and ensuring their sustainability. This latter recognizes the importance of continuous and adequate infrastructure maintenance. The project therefore promotes establishment of an efficient road maintenance system, based on a clearly defined sector strategy and prioritized works program, that includes: (a) creation of an autonomous Road Maintenance Fund (RMF) to mobilize resources for continuous maintenance financing; (b) reorganization of road maintenance institutions to facilitate involvement of the private sector and communities in infrastructure maintenance works; and (c) streamlined, transparent procurement and management procedures.
 4 2. TRANSPORT IN TOGO A. TRANSPORT SECTOR CONTEXT 2.1 The Togolese transport system is relatively well-developed, having evolved through strategic investment choices over the past 20 years. With adequate maintenance, this system has the capacity to respond to Togo's medium-term development needs. Road infrastructure consists of a dense road network (0.13 km/kM2), 9,600 km in length, of which 1,608 km are paved, 1,461 km are earth roads, and 4,500 km are improved rural tracks. The remainder consists of ordinary rural tracks. The principal axis, accommodating more than 50 percent of Togo's road traffic, is the international highway, RN1, running north from Lome to the border with Burkina Faso. The second major axis is the coastal road, linking Togo to Ghana and Benin. The rail network consists of 570 km of rail lines, of which only the 276 km line from Lome to Blitta is currently in use. The port at Lome, operated by an autonomous agency, is an important regional facility with large storage capacity and more than 800 meters of berth, able to accommodate up to 3 million tons a year; an open-sea wharf at Kpeme facilitates the export of phosphates. Air transport infrastructure consists of an international airport at Lome, with a yearly capacity of 700,000 travelers and 10,000 tons of freight, and 6 secondary national airports, including the airport at Niamtougou, which is operational but lacks commercial traffic. 2.2 Supply and Demand for Transport Services. Transport activities were profoundly affected by the crisis. Road traffic demand, which had been growing at an annual rate of 3 to 6 percent since 1980, dropped dramatically at the beginning of the 1990s to its lowest point since the beginning of the previous decade. The return to relative political stability in 1994 sparked a sectoral recovery, consolidated in 1995. However, it is unlikely that anticipated demand will lead to any real increased infrastructure capacity until 2002. After two decades of steady growth, Lome's port traffic fell from a 1990 high of 2 million tons to 1 million tons in 1993. Air traffic fell from 414,000 passengers and 6,512 tons of goods in 1991 to 191,000 passengers and 3,200 tons in 1994. Rail traffic has been declining steadily since 1975: passenger traffic had ceased entirely by 1996; freight traffic had fallen from 517,000 tons to 35,000 tons by 1994. 2.3 Road transport supply is diversified and adequate. Liberalized in the early eighties, road transport responds to more than 98 percent of the domestic demand for transport of passengers and freight; the remainder goes by rail. In 1995, the national fleet was estimated at 32,000 cars, vans and trucks. At least 75 percent of this fleet is comprised of imported used vehicles, generally in poor condition. Interurban passenger
 5 transport is provided by small-scale private operators operating some 1,100 minibuses and jitneys. Freight transport services are provided by 3 private companies and by multiple, small (one to two-truck), individual carriers. Estimates suggest that there may be some 1,300 trucks in the fleet. Since the disappearance in the early 1980s of the municipal bus company, urban and periurban passenger traffic has been provided by the informal sector. Urban transport, mainly in Lome, is provided by small operators, driving taxis, minivans, and motorcycle taxis. The motorcycle taxis, an inexpensive transport mode, proliferated with the economic crisis, providing employment and easy access to urban areas with poor infrastructure. B. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL SITUATION OF THE SECTOR 2.4 Sector Importance to the Economy. For Togo, reliable and efficient transport service is essential to the competitiveness of its main economic pillars: agriculture and trade. In addition, Togo's geographic location is such that its transport system plays a vital role in the development of regional transit trade, especially for the landlocked countries of Niger, Burkina Faso, and Mali, as well as the neighboring countries of Benin and Ghana. This transit activity has an important impact on the Togolese economy. 2.5 Transport Sector Contribution to Economic Development. The most recent estimate of the actual value-added of the transport sector to GDP dates back to 1990. Extrapolation from this data gives a 1995 transport sector contribution to GDP of 5 to 6 percent. This figure only partially reflects the real contribution to the national economic growth, as it does not capture the contributions of numerous small-scale or informal transport operations (estimated at 74 percent of total value-added for the transport sector), which are difficult to measure. The latest value-added figures by transport mode, covering 1985-1990, show that: (a) transport as a whole contributed between 6.5 percent and 7 percent to GDP, and that (b) the dominant contribution comes from road transport (65 to 70 percent of the total value-added for the transport sector), followed by that of maritime transport at (13 to 17 percent). Direct employment in the sector was estimated in 1995 at the equivalent of 26,500 permanent jobs, mainly in the transport of goods and passengers; 80 percent of this employment is in private sector. Hence the transport sector is an important supplier of employment. 2.6 Road Sector Finance. Road taxes and charges contribute around 10 percent of General Budget revenues. Sectoral resources come from four tax sources: (a) customs and excise taxes on imported petroleum products (61 percent of sector tax revenue); (b) import duties on vehicles and spare parts; (c) taxes on road carrier revenues; and (d) excise and other taxes on some administrative services. Tax revenue fell sharply during the 1991-93 crisis, from CFAF 9 billion in 1990 to about 2.8 billion in 1993. As in the general economy, stability and the devaluation brought about a slight recovery in 1994, with revenues of CFAF 5.4 billion. The trend was consolidated in 1995 with a return to pre-crisis levels (CFAF 9.3 billion), which have continued to rise (over CFAF 10 billion in 1996). Transport sector revenue is expected to be on the order of CFAF 15 billion in 1997 following the recent increase in oil prices. Despite these resources, Budget allocations to road maintenance (approximately CFAF 1.2 billion) are insufficient to
 6 cover actual needs, estimated to average CFAF 3.0 billion for routine and periodic maintenance. C. SECTOR MANAGEMENT: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE STAKEHOLDERS The Public Sector 2.7 Transport Sector Management. Until recently, Togo's transport sector was managed by multiple public sector institutions. As recommended in the TSS, a government reshuffling in August 1996 brought most of these institutions under the supervision of the Ministry of Mines, Equipment, Transport, Posts and Telecommunications (MMETPT). The MMETPT, through its Secretariat d'Etat des Transports (State Transport Secretariat) (SET) and subsectoral departments, exercises State control functions (regulation, safety, sectoral policy, financial monitoring), and the administrative supervision of the 4 public and parastatal companies. Its Direction generale des Transports (DGT), formerly at the Ministere du Commerce des Transports et des Prix (Ministry of Trade, Transport and Prices) (MCTP) is responsible for sector policy design and implementation, regulates the system and supervises the government- owned companies in each of the sub-sectors. Legal and financial supervision of public and parastatal companies is the responsibility of the Ministere de l 'Industrie et des Entreprises publiques (Ministry of Industry and Public Enterprises). 2.8 Road Infrastructure Management. Table 2.1 provides a break-down of the areas of responsibility for Togo's road network. The national road infrastructure and some of the rural routes are under the MMETPT's Direction generale des Travaux Publics (General Directorate of Public Works) (DGTP). Management of the remaining network of rural roads and tracks is theoretically divided among the Ministry of Agriculture, Breeding and Fishing (MAEP), public agribusinesses (SOTOCO and SAFICC), and the prefectures. The DGTP is responsible for planning and managing the 1,660 km of paved and 1,461 km of unpaved roads which make up the national road network. In mid-1994, MMETPT became responsible for 943 km of improved rural roads, formerly under MAEP. The major agribusinesses were charged with managing road infrastructure serving the regions in which they operate: SOTOCO covered 2,040 km of earth roads in the cotton zone, while SAFICC covered 865 km of earth roads in the coffee and cocoa producing regions. These companies are currently being restructured, and rural infrastructure no longer falls under their jurisdiction. Around 1,154 km of rural road constructed through donor-supported agricultural and rural service improvement projects are not under the aegis of any formal or informal institution. The remainder of the network, consisting of dirt tracks, is theoretically under the authority of the prefectures, however these local authorities have neither the management capacity nor the necessary resources to see to its maintenance.

SET, through the Direction ginirale des Transports (DGT), is now responsible for road safety management including policy design and implementation. Police and the gendarmerie are responsible for traffic control, but their intervention does not address this basic objective and mainly results in extorting funds from drivers. Driver training and examinations are poor. The only institution presently attempting to address
 8 road safety is the Prevention Routiere togolaise (Togolese Road Safety Organization), a private association with no permanent staff or official status, whose only source of income is a once-yearly headlight inspection fee. The Private Sector 2.11 Interurban transport. As noted earlier, interurban transport is provided by numerous, small-scale, private operators. Ease of entry and liberalization of the activity have encouraged a rapid increase in supply. The interurban rolling stock is quite old: in 1995, the fleet was 12 years old on average, with 20 percent of the stock over 15 years old. The stock is replenished by imported used vehicles, a common regional phenomenon. Two drivers unions for passenger transport (USYNDICTO and SYLICONTO), and one freight transport union (UTRABO) play an important role in the functioning of interurban travel services by managing all stations, supervising the orderly rotation of vehicle loading, collecting fares for drivers, and regulating the various mandatory taxes. The unions also manage a solidarity fund of drivers' contributions as a service to members. 2.12 Urban transport. Urban transport is similarly provided by numerous small- scale, individual operators, the majority of which operate in the informal sector. The fleet of taxis and minibuses is old and in bad condition. Less than 30 percent of the vehicles are insured. Private sector operators enjoy free access to the road transport profession and a conducive regulatory framework, but suffer from an excess of supply and extortion by police at multiple checkpoints. 2.13 Local Public Works Sector. Experience with contracting out routine maintenance to local small and medium enterprises (SMEs) shows promise in promoting productivity. The 1993 IDA-funded Transport Rehabilitation Project (Cr. 1861-TO), promoted contracting out small repairs (patching, masonry, road repair) to SMEs. The European Development Fund (EDF) has also funded several routine maintenance operations through local SME contracting. In 1994-95, taking advantage of a restructuring in the Transport Rehabilitation Project, approximately 80 contracts for routine maintenance (patching, drainage system repair and cleaning, repaving, road shoulder repair) were awarded to some 30 SMEs. Despite structural weaknesses caused by inactivity during the 1991-93 political crisis, the SMEs proved effective in providing road maintenance. Further support would improve the management capacity of these SMEs, and enable them to carry out future works more efficiently. 2.14 Associations and Nongovernmental Organizations (NGOs). Togolese society is characterized by deep traditions of association and community, especially in rural areas, centered on the institution of "village chiefdoms." Since independence, new types of local social organization have emerged to promote local development, supported by larger domestic and international institutions. Today there are over 2,500 formal and informal associations of different types (NGOs, cooperatives, local associations) throughout the country involved in a variety of sectors, such as health, literacy, agricultural production and marketing, and rural infrastructure (mainly water and roads). The most wide-spread of these new organizations are some 1,500 village development
 9 committees, supported by the Ministry of Social Affairs, which organize village participation in local development activities. The 381 village agricultural groups, supported by the major agribusinesses (SOTOCO and SAFICC), organize and develop agricultural production in the agricultural export-producing zones. Other community organizations have developed since the end of the 1980s through international NGO development projects. By 1995, there were at least 20 local, and 5 international NGOs involved in rural infrastructure projects (water supply and feeder road management) throughout the country. This network of community associations suffers from a lack of material resources, of coordination with traditional institutions, and competence in specific areas of intervention. Despite these difficulties, the network of associations in Togo provides a strong foundation on which to build community participation in local development. D. LESSONS LEARNED FROM INVOLVEMENT OF THE WORLD BANK GROUP AND OTHER DONORS IN THE TOGOLESE TRANSPORT SECTOR Donor Involvement 2.15 The EDF and IDA are the major active donors in the transport sector. Other donors have provided significant assistance in the past: German Cooperation (KFW) in the development of the Port of Lome, the French Development Fund (CFD) in rural roads and airport infrastructure, and FIDA along with the United Nations Development Program in feeder road infrastructure. The African Development Bank (AfDB) has assisted Togo in paving and rehabilitating part of the national road network. Apart from IDA, EDF remains the major contributor to transport sector development through projects of road paving, construction of new feeder roads in cocoa and cotton-producing zones and routine and periodic maintenance of the national road network. EDF also supported development of the private construction sector in its last national road maintenance and rehabilitation operation (1990-1992). Donor assistance to Togo was interrupted by the 1991-93 political crisis, and is only beginning to resume, led by IDA in 1993, and shortly to be followed by AfDB. Other donors are willing to resume financing once Togo has complied with their political and institutional conditions. Past IDA Involvement 2.16 IDA has been associated with Togo's transport sector since 1968, and has led active donor assistance to the sector. It has financed seven sector projects, with a combined credit of US$ 133 million, of which six have been concluded and one is nearing completion. IDA has focused its lending on roads, as the most important of the country's transport infrastructure, but has also supported a rail operation. Of IDA's support to the road sector, five projects have dealt primarily with national roads, one project focused on feeder roads and one project addressed both. Taken together, the IDA projects constitute a significant and prolonged effort which has achieved some, though not fully satisfactory, results. Despite major achievements, inadequate road maintenance has remained the leading sector issue.
 10 2.17 The soon-to-be-completed Transport Rehabilitation Project (CR. 1861-TO) aimed at achieving major sectoral reforms to facilitate private sector involvement in road maintenance, develop public sector management capacity, improve road safety and secure road maintenance funding. However, project implementation was severely hampered by the political and economic crises of the early 1 990s. The project was restructured in 1994 to focus on priority maintenance for the national network and on rebuilding road network administration capacity. Lessons Learned 2.18 Six major lessons flow from IDA project experience in Togo's transport sector: (a) Current arrangements for road maintenance financing are inadequate. Resources for road maintenance financing are allocated in the National General Budget by the Treasurer. Although the funding exists on paper, it has never been provided in full or on time, even during periods of fiscal soundness. Adequate road maintenance financing could be ensured by an independently financed, autonomous fund, governed by road user representatives and other sector stakeholders. (b) The force account has proven to be seriously ineffective in carrying out maintenance of road networks, despite support and supervision efforts. Force account labor is oversupplied, underskilled and poorly supervised, resulting in low productivity. New equipment deteriorates quickly due to poor maintenance, and inappropriate use. Maintenance works should be contracted out to take advantage of competition and wider skills. (c) Administrative obstacles and excessive control by high level bureaucrats are stifling sector institutions, and prevent them from developing adequate competencies and responding to sector needs. Cumbersome procedures, especially in procurement, a top-heavy hierarchy, and lack of resources have discouraged initiative and destroyed capacity-building efforts in previous operations. Procurement procedures should be revised and simplified, and institutions should be restructured to facilitate accountability and individual initiative. (d) Entrenched long-term technical assistance (TA) and untargeted training have proven ineffective. TA should be short-term and focused on beneficiary needs. Likewise training should correspond to beneficiary-identified needs, and be provided on site, whenever possible, by qualified trainers. TRANSPORT SECTOR ISSUES AND STRATEGY The 1995 Transport Sector Strategy 2.19 A Participatory Process. Within the framework of its economic revitalization program, the Government of Togo identified the need to define a transport sector development strategy to reestablish sectoral efficacy and allow it to play its role in restoring national economic competitiveness. The Transport Sector Strategy was developed through intensive stakeholder participation and consultation, and consisted of the following principle steps: (a) analysis of sectoral issues and identification of priorities and strategic directions; (b) Government discussions of analysis results with public and private stakeholders (including local sectoral professional organizations), World Bank missions, and other donors; and (c) a three-day national seminar at the end of November 1995 organized by the Togolese authorities to discuss and widen consensus on the strategic recommendations resulting from this process. The seminar facilitated discussion and issue resolution among the widest possible arena of sector stakeholders, including the private sector, professional organizations, and formal and informal groups of transport service users, in addition to public sector entities and donors. 2.20 Infrastructure maintenance is the priority. The TSS concludes that maintenance and better use of existing investments take priority over new investments. This conclusion translates into two fundamental sector priorities: (a) to rehabilitate road infrastructure, and establish an effective maintenance system; and (b) to modernize the institutional environment to make best use of the comparative advantages of the public and private sectors. Road infrastructure is singled out for particular emphasis because, while port and airport infrastructure and services are financially self-reliant and provide adequate service to their users, road infrastructure has fallen into critical condition due to lack of maintenance, leading to a continuously declining level of service and increasing transport costs. 2.21 Within the framework of this strategy, the GOT has defined the following concrete measures in the TSIP to achieve the priorities set above: (a) initiate a road network rehabilitation and maintenance program, meeting economic and financial criteria, that includes: (i) establishment of an autonomous Road Maintenance Fund to ensure adequate and regular maintenance financing, (ii) encouragement of, and eventual full reliance on the private sector to carry out road maintenance, and (iii) standardized management of rural roads, and participation of rural communities in maintenance works; and (b) strengthen the institutional framework and improve administrative capacity to manage and plan the sector, including road safety.
 12 Road Infrastructure Management: Issues and Strategy Issues 2.22 A well structured road network that could, if adequately maintained, easily meet mid-term demand. The Togolese road network consists of the national network and the rural road network (see Table 2.1). The national network is formed by a set of north- south radial highways, centered on Lome, which cross a set of east-west roads. The network includes roads linking prefectures and international highways, the most important of which is RN 1, linking Lome to the Burkina Faso and Niger borders (Cinkasse) in the north. RN1 is complemented by a coastal road crossing from Ghana to Cotonou. The network of radial roads is relatively well developed and most of it is paved. 2.23 Of Togo's 8,000 to 9,000 km of road, 3,133 km are national roads and 5,000 to 6,000 km are rural roads. About 54 percent of the national network is paved; the remainder consists of gravel or earth roads. The rural road network encompasses rural roads that have been upgraded under a variety of social and agricultural projects, and rural paths that have never been improved. 2.24 A road network in critical condition. The 1990-93 political turmoil and resultant fiscal crisis have taken a heavy toll on road infrastructure. Over the last six years, disorganized public administrationand lack of government finance has limited road maintenance solely to curative operations on the most damaged routes (those in danger of complete closure), financed by foreign assistance. The total lack of periodic or even routine maintenance over the last six years has resulted in increasing degradation of all routes. A network inspection conducted in late 1995 showed that 63 percent of the paved and 80 percent of the unpaved national network are in a bad to fair condition. Road degradation was aggravated by: (a) the suspension of external aid, which had been nearly the sole source of periodic maintenance financing; (b) an already aging network, 50 percent of which is an average of 15 years old; and (c) inadequate technical design of at least 50 percent of paved roads, making them extremely sensitive to the lack of maintenance. The national earth road network is now also in poor condition, but the effects of inadequate maintenance have been mitigated somewhat by a decline in traffic during the crisis. The most vulnerable sections of this network must be rehabilitated soon if interruptions in traffic flow, particularly during rainy seasons, are to be prevented in the years to come. 2.25 Weak road management capacity, an ill-adapted maintenance policy, inefficient force-account operations and insufficient financing of road maintenance The DGTP is adequately organized, but suffers from a lack of staff management, absence of a training policy and lack of professionals qualified in the areas of road maintenance, planning and works supervision. The maintenance policy, subject to the vagaries of foreign aid, is ill-adapted and costly, giving priority to heavy rehabilitation works at the expense of regular routine and periodic maintenance. This policy is revealed in distribution of maintenance expenditures over the last ten years: 2 percent for periodic maintenance, 20 percent for routine maintenance and 78 percent for rehabilitationworks
 13 2.26 Routine maintenance, when performed, is executed by DGTP through its decentralized force account. Although force-account brigades have abundant staffand equipment, they have low productivityand lack flexibility. Force-accountinefficiency stems from: (a) insufficient budget resources; (b) slow commitment and disbursement procedures, limiting the actual amount of disposable resources; (c) inadequate supervision and monitoring, compounded by poor programming; and (d) ill-adapted administrative procedures, especially in procurement. DGTP management of public works equipment is deficient. As a result, the fleet (262 vehicles) is deteriorating and less than 40 percent is currently available for use. There is virtually no control of equipment use. 2.27 Local SME development, which could increase the country's road maintenance capacity, is severely constrained by lengthy contracting and payment procedures for public procurement and the lack of a stable, sustainable market. These factors destroy any incentive for SMEs to invest in developing human or material capital. 2.28 Maintenanceprogramming, currently limitedto curative maintenance, is overly simplistic and inefficient. Data necessary for effective maintenance programming, such as condition of network, past maintenance, traffic counts, network inspections, are virtually non-existent. The network has deteriorated to the point that programming must focus on emergency maintenance, with limited prioritization. Investment programming seems to be largely ad hoc, especially for rehabilitationworks, with no economicjustification. 2.29 Government budget allocations for road maintenance are inadequate and irregular (around CFAF 1.2 billion, whereas annual maintenance requirements reach CFAF 3.0 billion). Untimely release of funds delays commitment and disbursement. Budget utilization is hampered by burdensome paperwork procedures imposed by the Treasury. In addition, a substantial part of the allocated budget covers the fixed operating costs of the DGTP, thus limiting the amount actually available for maintenance works. 2.30 In addition to the issues described above, the rural road network suffers from multiple interventions with no coordination. Rural network management is supposedly distributed among a number of agencies, as shown in Table 2.1. Much of this network either falls betweenjurisdictions, or suffers from weak institutional management capacity. In 1994 the MMETPT, through the DGTP, assumed responsibility for management of 943 km of rural roads previously under control of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development. Agribusiness companies (SOTOCO and SAFICC) also are theoretically in charge of the rural track network serving their production area, though most of the network is not identified. SOTOCO has occasionally undertaken road maintenance works with CFD support; otherwise neither company has invested in road maintenance. Investment decisions largely depend on the availability of foreign financing with no coordination among Togolese institutions and donors, which often leads to these resources being wasted. Most of the improved rural tracks were built without providing resources or determining responsibility for their future maintenance. Construction standards for some tracks are too high for the role they are expected to play and the actual traffic they handle.

 35 4. BENEFITS, IMPACTS AND RISKS A. ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 4.1 Project Benefits. All road improvement will reduce transport time and vehicle operating costs, leading to a reduction in overall transport costs. Reduction of transport costs will lower the cost of transported goods, encouraging agricultural production and trade. Reduction of transport costs will likewise lower passenger fares, encouraging mobility. Other, non-quantifiable benefits are expected to flow from IDA-supported activities that improve management and planning. Effective use of the priority program as an investment tool should result in higher rates of return on investments in the transport sector as a whole. Development of a community-based, demand-driven rural roads maintenance strategy will lead to more effective use of resources. Better planning and contract management, based on improved road data, will enable maintenance of more roads with the same budget. Improvements in road safety will reduce the cost of traffic accidents in terms of human life and productivity, and damage to vehicles. Economic analyses for individual IDA components are summarized below, and detailed in Annex E. 4.2 Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance. Economic analysis undertaken during preparation covered all road sector investments for the Government's ten-year program. Even though the four IDA components are but part of this larger priority program, economic analysis of the larger program facilitates rational selection of investments by IDA and other donors. This analysis included a section-by-section review of proposed trouble spot repairs, regraveling and rehabilitation of unpaved roads, and definition of optimal maintenance strategies for both the paved and unpaved road networks. ERRs were also calculated for maintenance cost flows. Cost streams include the cost of works required to bring key sections of the network up to a service level at which regular maintenance is viable, in addition to maintenance costs. Benefits are taken to be savings in vehicle operating costs due to improved road surfaces; time savings were not included. The base case is defined as continuation of the lowest level of service, or deterioration to this level, at which vehicles can still actually use the road. This is the only way to generate a baseline level of vehicle operating costs, which may then be compared to the "with-investment" level. In practice, it should be noted, in a case in which no road maintenance is undertaken, roads become impassable and traffic virtually ceases. Only minimum maintenance costs are included in the base case, since, in their present state, some roads cannot even be maintained without remedial repair to upgrade their standard to a minimum required to maintain traffic flows.
 36 4.3 Paved road works include only rehabilitation of badly deteriorated sections of the interurban network. Cost-benefit analyses were carried out during program preparation using the Highway Design Model (HDM). Rehabilitation design and work costs were based on technical standards developed during TSS preparation, and recent works costs provided by the DGTP. The HDM vehicle operating cost module was calibrated to account for used cars, which make up the core of Togo's vehicle fleet. The results of the economic analysis are shown in Annex E. The ERR of the priority program over the paved network is about 460 percent. The total Net Present Value (NPV) at a 12 percent discount rate, is estimated at CFAF 440 billion, while the Net Present Cost is estimated at CFAF 37 billion. The rehabilitation of the three road sections (Lom6-Ts6vi6, Tsevi& Noste, Attakpam6-Blitta) as currently proposed for IDA financing shows a very high ERR (infinite or 192 percent). Additional program financing is still being sought, in any case the IDA Credit will participate in the financing of the rehabilitation of one of the most deteriorated section of RN1. Sensitivity analysis shows that a drop in the rate of patching from 50 to 20 percent would reduce the NPV of the proposed investment by 4 percent, and raise overall maintenance costs by 4 percent. This demonstrates the need for regularly performed routine maintenance over the life-span of the network (see Annex E). 4.4 An optimal maintenance strategy for the unpaved road network was defined' building on empirical evidence of road deterioration and earth road maintenance experience in Togo and neighboring countries. The objective is to optimize the allocation of road maintenance resources so as to maximize the number of practicable itineraries. The optimal maintenance strategy for a given section maximizes the present value of the difference between the cost of maintenance works and user cost savings. A 12 percent discount rate was used. Cost-benefit analysis was also carried out to rank reviewed' sections and select priorities. Vehicle operating costs were determined- using HDM with appropriate adjustments for composition of traffic using the-earth road network. Cost of works was based on private sector contracting. The ERRs for works on the 51 stretches of unpaved national roads proposed for IDA financing range from 340 percent to -2 percent, depending on'the section. The NPV, at'a 12 percent discount rate, is estimated at CFAF 59 billion.' Works programming is directly prioritized by key economic advantages, and only those sections with an ERR higher than 12 percent and positive NPV will be considered under this project (49 sections, see- Annex E for more details). 4.5 Sensitivity analyses were conducted over different values for the most important variables: level of traffic (30 percent less than estimated), level of service over the entire network (fair), and cost of works (30 percent more than estimated). Economic returns remain high for the most heavily trafficked sections. However, ERRs for sections with ERRs less than 20 percent in the Base Case dropped dramatically: 4 sections showed ERRs under the 12 percent project inclusion ceiling. Following-this analysis, the project would finance only the most heavily trafficked unpaved roads (first and second priority option).
 37 4.6 While it is not possible to quantify the benefits of the other activities financed under this component (road safety improvement, institutional strengthening, training and studies for improved management, strengthening of SMEs, and overall IDA Credit management), these activities will certainly generate benefits by lowering traffic accident rates, improving the efficiency of resource use, and encouraging competition in the private construction sector. 4.7 Feeder Road Management. There is no reliable data or approach to estimate increased revenues for the beneficiaries of pilot rural areas from the additional agricultural production, and better access to markets and services, which improved road conditions are expected to induce. Farmers can be expected to make rational choices on the sections of road to be proposed for rehabilitation and maintenance, based on their own assessment of benefits likely to accrue to them. The component has been designed, in fact, to apply selection criteria used in Government-sponsored programs, which take into account user savings, increased agricultural production, and social and poverty impacts.  1 Executive summary 1. The project will aim at rehabilitating Togo's main road and rural roads network and setting the bases for its long term maintenance. Since no new roads will be opened up in the framework of the project, the expected environmental impacts will be milder than in the case of new roads. In addition, the project will encourage labor intensive road maintenance activities that are generally more environmentally friendly than highly mechanized activities. An environmental assessment has been undertaken, during which 1.700 km of roads have been observed in all ecological areas of the country, consultations have been undertaken with rural and urban populations affected by road rehabilitation initiatives, and all key administrative bodies have been contacted. Field observations revealed that the project will have minor negative environmental impacts that can be easily mitigated. The dirt roads are in acceptable condition, which will only require mild rehabilitation by resurfacing and eliminating critical points. The tarred roads are in variable conditions, certain tracks will require heavy rehabilitation in the short term. On a social standpoint, the consultative approach that has been retained for the rehabilitation of rural roads will ensure that the needs of the rural people will be taken into account when selecting rural roads to be rehabilitated. 2. The main environmental impacts and the accompanying mitigation measures will be: * Laterite quarries that are opened up along the roads and that, if not rehabilitated after use, could induce erosion and standing waters. The rehabilitation of these areas is technically straighfforward and easily implemented. On a case by case approach, these quarries may be restored by leveling the grounds and spreading back organic soil on the area, vegetative cover may then be restored through tree planting or grass propagation. In other cases, laterite quarries may be transformed into water reservoirs that would greatly benefit the local populations. Wetlands may be harmed by road crossing and ineffective road drainage infrastructure, this may lead to an imbalance of fragile ecosystems, loss of agricultural land used during the dry season, and eutrophication of certain water bodies, in addition to ecological losses due to the degradation of the ecosystems. The project will improve drainage infrastructure, which will result in the restoration of the original water transfers that naturally regulate wetlands. The drainage of roads (runoff waters) sometimes leads to the accelerated formation of gullies and to erosion alongside the roads. It has generally been observed that the present drainage infrastructure carries water to areas with adequate vegetative cover and that erosion is
 2 generally not exacerbated by road drainage. Guidelines include provisions for improving the downstream portion of road drainage systems. Atmospheric pollution linked to road rehabilitation and maintenance is very low and negligible compared to other sources of air pollution such as general passenger and freight vehicles traffic. The main problem at present is the dust generated by major rehabilitation works which can cause discomfort and health hazards to local populations, as well as mild damage to nearby crops or natural vegetation. This is easily controlled by frequent watering of construction sites which is already widely practiced by road construction companies. * The destruction of human habitat is rarely a problem. In the few cases where households had to be evicted, compensation measures not satisfactory. Population displacement will not take place under this project. 3. In urban an peri-urban zones environmental impacts and mitigation measures are the following: The limited infiltration surface that characterizes urban areas increases the risks of flooding, especially when taking into consideration the almost level topography of the major cities of southern Togo. The reconstruction of urban drainage infrastructure, their maintenance, and the paving instead of tarring of roads, all undertaken within the project, greatly improve the water drainage situation in urban areas. * Atmospheric pollution issues are more serious in urban areas due to the density of traffic, the large affected population, and the limited airflow that characterizes them. Even more care is generally taken by road construction companies in order to minimize dust displacement. Vehicle emissions could be greatly diminished by instating vehicle pollution standards and an inspection system. A different methodology was used to determine an optimal maintenance strategy for the unpaved road network. The main objective of this methodology was to optimize allocation of road maintenance resources in order to maximize the number of passable itineraries. Under this methodology, maintenance activities for each road section must be tailored to actual traffic levels, terrain and weather conditions to determine the service level that optimizes the overall balance between user cost savings and maintenance costs. Thus, the optimal strategy was based on empirical evidence of road deterioration at given traffic and maintenance levels, and on maintenance experience and observations of earth road conditions in Togo and neighboring countries with a similar road network. The optimal maintenance strategy will minimize the present value of the aggregate net maintenance cost for each road section. The net cost on a given section is defined as the difference between the cost of maintenance (routine and periodic), and the user costs for vehicles using the road section; the Net Present Value (NPV) of the annual stream of net costs is calculated over 20 years at a 12 percent discount rate. doc.abstracts: The Road Transport Project, an International Development Agency (IDA) project will address the most important priorities of the Road Sector Investment Program (RSIP) to complement and reinforce IDA s ongoing assistance to support Togo s economic recovery and sustained growth. Specifically, the project will support operations to a) rehabilitate and maintain both national and rural roads; b) provide regular and stable road maintenance financing from local resources; c) encourage private sector involvement in subsector development; d) improve road safety; and e) revitalize and strengthen the management capacity of transport sector institutions. The IDA Credit will finance works, goods, and services for four components: 1) remedial maintenance or rehabilitation and regraveling of the paved road network, critical sections of the rural road network, and the most important sections of the national unpaved network to improve their condition to a level facilitating sustainable maintenance; 2) institutional strengthening of public sector management capacity to improve sector coordination, investment planning and monitoring, road maintenance programming and implementation, and to facilitate private sector involvement in transport and public works; 3) road safety improvement, including building and equipping a vehicle inspection center, technical assistance and studies, collection and analysis of traffic accident data, school and public road safety campaigns, and training instructors and examiners; and 4) building mechanisms for beneficiary and community participation in rural road management capacity.
